Award.AwardTitle: Development of a 0.5 Tesla AF Demagnetizer
Award.AbstractNarration:
1053399
Coe

This grant support the development of a new high magnetic field capable (0.5-1.0 Tesla) single axis Alternating Field (AF) Demagnetizer to support research in rock and paleomagnetism. The design would incorporate a magnetic core, built from high magnetic permeability material, in an air-cooled coil producing a uniform field oriented transverse to the sample bore. The PIs will first build a 0.5 T AF demag system and then will attempt the more challenging 1.0 T design. A successful device will yield a much higher peak alternating field than available on existing commercial devices (a factor of 5-6 higher field) and enable demagnetization of many samples that currently cannot be demagnetized via alternative methods without generating spurious primary remanent magnetizations, particularly rocks that contain magnetic minerals that are chemically altered using thermal demagnetization techniques. It will also offer the ability to characterize the magnetic mineralogy of sedimentary rocks through examination of coercivity distributions derived from AF demagnetization of magnetic remanence. The developed instrument will support collaborative research in rock and paleomagnetism. The PIs will engage undergraduates in some aspects of the development effort.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have designed, built and tested a better alternating-field demagnetizer than previously existed that will extend the experimental capability of today's paleomagnetic laboratories. Earth scientists study the paleomagnetism, that is, the ancient magnetization, of rocks to gain information about their age, the movement of the continents and tectonic plates, and the behavior and origin of Earth's magnetic field. Virtually all paleomagnetic laboratories use the technique of alternating-field (AF) demagnetization to strip away younger, secondary components of magnetization to reveal the primary magnetization that was acquired when the rock formed. But even the best AF demagnetizers in use today can remove only a fraction of the secondary magnetization that obscures the primary component of some rocks. The difficulty with these rocks is that a part of their magnetization, including their secondary magnetization, is so stable that today's demagnetizers cannot generate high enough alternating fields to erase them. 

     To overcome this problem we have developed a demagnetizer that produces AF fields three to five times higher than currently available instruments. To do this we introduced a magnetic core into the electrical coil that generates the field. This is the usual technique in electromagnets, electric motors and transformers to produce fields higher than can be achieved with air cores, but it has not been used in AF demagnetization devices since it was tried and abandoned long ago due to nonlinear effects, dissipation, and residual fields that the magnetic cores then available produced. But today new materials are on the market with much better properties, such as the Metglas alloy that we use. Together with the programmable control afforded by digital electronics, we have succeeded in overcoming these and other earlier problems.

   Our AF demagnetizer produces fields up to 700 mT (millitesla), significantly higher than our original design goal of 500 mT. We have tested it successfully on igneous, sedimentary, and meteorite samples. In all cases our results join smoothly to the 0 to 180 mT demagnetization curves obtained with our commercial instrument and continue them up to much higher fields. Production of spurious anhysteretic magnetization was negligible, and passive cooling of the coils in air during operation was sufficient to prevent overheating. Soon we will begin to reap the benefits of greater demagnetization capability in our research.

     Scientists from many paleomagnetic laboratories have expressed interest in obtaining or building an AF demagnetizer like ours. A couple of companies that develop and market paleomagnetic instruments have also contacted us. In March 2016 we published a technical paper that describes many details of our design. Having no interest oursleves in making instruments to sell, we are happy to share everything we have learned with any and all comers.
